items.title: Cannot use Google Ads API versions 3 or 4 with python
items.body:
Issues:

- No module named 'google.ads.google_ads.v4'
- Specified Google Ads API version "v4" does not exist. Valid API versions are: "v2", "v1"

For months, I've been stuck in version 2 of the Google Ads API.
Now that version 4 has things necessary to run my business, I really need to use it and can't postpone solving my issue anymore.
The issue is that whatever I run a python code with version 4, I get this error (equivalent error when I try version 3):
ValueError: Specified Google Ads API version "v4" does not exist. Valid API versions are: "v2", "v1"

My Python google-ads api version is updated to version 6.0 (currently the latest). I am using Anaconda with Python 3.7.4 and 3.7.7 (currently the latest). Whether I use Jupyter or Spyder, I get the same error message.
I tried uninstalling google-ads library (pip uninstall google-ads), but the kernel never stops working, even if I let it run the uninstall for an entire night. Maybe this is a tip to the root cause?
I tried to run the code below as an example, which Google makes available in its documentation, but other codes of my own that work in version 2 get the same error and don't work on versions 3 or 4.

#!/usr/bin/env python
"""This example illustrates how to get campaign criteria.
Retrieves negative keywords in a campaign.
"""

import sys

from google.ads.google_ads.client import GoogleAdsClient
from google.ads.google_ads.errors import GoogleAdsException

def main(client, customer_id):
    ga_service = client.get_service('GoogleAdsService', version='v4')

    query = ('SELECT campaign.id, campaign.name, ad_group.id, ad_group.name, '
             'ad_group_criterion.criterion_id, '
             'ad_group_criterion.keyword.text, '
             'ad_group_criterion.keyword.match_type, '
             'metrics.impressions, metrics.clicks, metrics.cost_micros '
             'FROM keyword_view WHERE segments.date DURING LAST_7_DAYS '
             'AND campaign.advertising_channel_type = \'SEARCH\' '
             'AND ad_group.status = \'ENABLED\' '
             'AND ad_group_criterion.status IN (\'ENABLED\', \'PAUSED\') '
             'ORDER BY metrics.impressions DESC '
             'LIMIT 50')

    # Issues a search request using streaming.
    response = ga_service.search_stream(customer_id, query)
    keyword_match_type_enum = client.get_type(
        'KeywordMatchTypeEnum', version='v4').KeywordMatchType
    try:
        for batch in response:
            for row in batch.results:
                campaign = row.campaign
                ad_group = row.ad_group
                criterion = row.ad_group_criterion
                metrics = row.metrics
                keyword_match_type = keyword_match_type_enum.Name(
                    criterion.keyword.match_type)
                print(f'Keyword text "{criterion.keyword.text.value}" with '
                      f'match type "{keyword_match_type}" '
                      f'and ID {criterion.criterion_id.value} in '
                      f'ad group "{ad_group.name.value}" '
                      f'with ID "{ad_group.id.value}" '
                      f'in campaign "{campaign.name.value}" '
                      f'with ID {campaign.id.value} '
                      f'had {metrics.impressions.value} impression(s), '
                      f'{metrics.clicks.value} click(s), and '
                      f'{metrics.cost_micros.value} cost (in micros) during '
                      'the last 7 days.')
    except GoogleAdsException as ex:
        print(f'Request with ID "{ex.request_id}" failed with status '
              f'"{ex.error.code().name}" and includes the following errors:')
        for error in ex.failure.errors:
            print(f'\tError with message "{error.message}".')
            if error.location:
                for field_path_element in error.location.field_path_elements:
                    print(f'\t\tOn field: {field_path_element.field_name}')
        sys.exit(1)


if __name__ == '__main__':
    google_ads_client = GoogleAdsClient.load_from_storage( 'THE PATH TO MY GOOGLE ADS YAML FILE' )
    main(google_ads_client, 'MY CUSTOMER ID')

--
Please, what should I do?

items.title: Google ads API client doesn't work when using pyinstaller
items.body:
Im creating a tool to manage UAC assets, utilizing both adwords and google-ads API.

Im now trying to package the tool and have decided that the best way to deliver it was bundling it up as an executable using pyinstaller.

Once i bundle the app, i run the resulted executable and the API calls i make using the adwords API work just fine, but the ones im trying to make using the google-ads API doesn't work.

To be more specific - when trying to create a client using this call:

`ga_service = client.get_service('GoogleAdsService', version='v2')`

i get the following errors:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "google/ads/google_ads/client.py", line 72, in _get_api_services_by_version
  File "importlib/__init__.py", line 126, in import_module
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 994, in _gcd_import
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 971, in _find_and_load
  File "<frozen importlib._bootstrap>", line 953, in _find_and_load_unlocked
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'google.ads.google_ads.v2'

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "flask/app.py", line 2284, in wsgi_app
  File "flask/app.py", line 1807, in full_dispatch_request
  File "flask/app.py", line 1710, in handle_user_exception
  File "flask/_compat.py", line 35, in reraise
  File "flask/app.py", line 1805, in full_dispatch_request
  File "flask/app.py", line 1791, in dispatch_request
  File "assetMG.py", line 73, in get_all_accounts_assets
    return get_specific_accounts_assets(cid)
  File "assetMG.py", line 86, in get_specific_accounts_assets
    res = get_accounts_assets(googleads_client, cid)
  File "app/backend/get_all_assets.py", line 33, in get_accounts_assets
    ga_service = client.get_service('GoogleAdsService', version=version)
  File "google/ads/google_ads/client.py", line 216, in get_service
  File "google/ads/google_ads/client.py", line 76, in _get_api_services_by_version
ValueError: Specified Google Ads API version "v2" does not exist. Valid API versions are: "v2", "v1"
```

What I believe happens, is that since i "freeze" the app using pyinstller, the google-ads client library is not able to dynamically import the module according to the version i specified during runtime. As seen in this function:

```
    @classmethod
    def _get_api_services_by_version(cls, version):
        """Returns a module with all services and types for a given API version.

        Args:
            version: a str indicating the API version.

        Returns:
            A module containing all services and types for the a API version.
        """
        try:
            version_module = import_module('google.ads.google_ads.%s' % version)
        except ImportError:
            raise ValueError('Specified Google Ads API version "{}" does not '
                             'exist. Valid API versions are: "{}"'.format(
                                 version, '", "'.join(_VALID_API_VERSIONS)))
        return version_module
```

Can you please advise? Any ideas on how to workaround that?

Thanks,
Eylon

items.title: Problem with `TargetRestrictionOperation` and `FeedAttributeOperation` enums

labels.name: P2
labels.description: Work that should be prioritized. Bugs classified here have known reasonable workarounds.

items.body: There seems to still be a few problems with the `enums.py` files after the recent fix. Specifically, dynamically creating the enums for `TargetRestrictionOperation` and `FeedAttributeOperation` in the v3 version fail because the name of the inner class in the string is different from the class attribute they're stored in (triggering an assertion error in `_CreateEnumTypeUponFirstAccess.__getattribute__`), while in the v2 version `FeedAttributeOperation` fails because of incorrect indentation inside the string.

items.title: Star imports from `v2/__init__.py` and `v3/__init__.py` fail

labels.name: P2
labels.description: Work that should be prioritized. Bugs classified here have known reasonable workarounds.

items.body: `from google.ads.google_ads.v2 import *` and `from google.ads.google_ads.v3 import *` fail with `AttributeError: unknown sub-module 'Enums'.` This happens because `__all__` is defined to contain uppercase versions of all the keys in `_lazy_name_to_package_map`. This works for the services since there is a corresponding uppercase type for each snake case module, but the dict also contains `types` and `enums`, for which this is not the case.

items.title: Threads created and not destroyed with each client

labels.name: P1
labels.description: Breaking issue affecting some users or workflows

items.body:
Each time you search on a client, new threads are created that are not destroyed. e.g. if you need to use many clients and run 

```python
def test():
    auth_string = """****"""
    client = google_ads.client.GoogleAdsClient.load_from_string(auth_string)
    service = client.get_service("GoogleAdsService")
    res = service.search(
        "****", "select campaign.resource_name from campaign limit 1"
    )
    res = list(res)


for i in range(10000):
    test()
```
Then run `watch -n1 "ps -eLf | wc -l"` in another terminal, you can see the number of threads creeping up. After a while you'll reach your machines thread limit then have lots of system wide problems. 

If you comment out the last line turning the results generator into a list, the problem disappears, so I think the thread creation is occurring there? 

As far as I can tell there isn't a `.close()` function on the client or service I'm missing?

items.title: Set policy_validation_parameter.ignorable_policy_topics when updating using AdService
items.body:

items.title: Memory climbing while adding and removing ad group audiences

labels.name: P1
labels.description: Breaking issue affecting some users or workflows

items.body:
I've been writing a script which is adding audiences to all the ad groups in an account, and found that the memory usage was climbing and not falling with garbage collection. I've reduced the problem to this example:
```
from google.ads.google_ads.client import GoogleAdsClient
from pprint import pprint
import argparse
import os
import psutil

parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description="Add audiences to accounts")
parser.add_argument(
    "-c", "--customer_id", type=str, required=True, help="The Google Ads customer ID."
)
parser.add_argument(
    "-a", "--ad_group_id", type=str, required=True, help="The ad group ID."
)

args = parser.parse_args()


def main():
    client = GoogleAdsClient.load_from_storage()
    ga_service = client.get_service("GoogleAdsService", version="v2")

    audience_ids = [ # All the affinity audiences
        93017,
        92601,
        93040,
        ...
    ]
    account_id = args.customer_id
    ad_group_id = args.ad_group_id
    ad_group_service = client.get_service("AdGroupService", version="v2")
    resource_name = ad_group_service.ad_group_path(account_id, ad_group_id)

    operations = []
    for audience_id in audience_ids:
        operations.append(
            create_add_ad_group_audience_operation(
                client, account_id, resource_name, audience_id
            )
        )

    add_audiences_to_ad_groups(client, account_id, operations)
    remove_audiences_from_ad_group(client, ga_service, account_id, ad_group_id)


def create_add_ad_group_audience_operation(client, account_id, ad_group, audience_id):
    ad_group_criterion_operation = client.get_type(
        "AdGroupCriterionOperation", version="v2"
    )
    ad_group_criterion = ad_group_criterion_operation.create

    user_interest_service = client.get_service("UserInterestService", version="v2")
    ad_group_criterion.user_interest.user_interest_category.value = user_interest_service.user_interest_path(
        account_id, audience_id
    )

    ad_group_criterion.ad_group.value = ad_group
    return ad_group_criterion_operation


def add_audiences_to_ad_groups(client, account_id, add_audience_to_ad_group_operations):
    ad_group_criterion_service = client.get_service(
        "AdGroupCriterionService", version="v2"
    )

    perform_ad_group_criterion_operations(
        ad_group_criterion_service, account_id, add_audience_to_ad_group_operations
    )


def perform_ad_group_criterion_operations(
    ad_group_criterion_service, account_id, operations
):
    ad_group_criterion_response = ad_group_criterion_service.mutate_ad_group_criteria(
        account_id, operations
    )


def remove_audiences_from_ad_group(client, ga_service, account_id, ad_group_id):
    query = f"""
        SELECT ad_group_criterion.resource_name
        FROM ad_group_criterion
        WHERE ad_group.id={ad_group_id}
            AND ad_group_criterion.type=USER_INTEREST
    """

    audiences = perform_query(ga_service, account_id, query)

    operations = []
    for audience in audiences:
        operations.append(
            create_remove_ad_group_audience_operation(
                client, account_id, audience.ad_group_criterion.resource_name
            )
        )

    ad_group_criterion_service = client.get_service(
        "AdGroupCriterionService", version="v2"
    )
    perform_ad_group_criterion_operations(
        ad_group_criterion_service, account_id, operations
    )


def perform_query(ga_service, customer_id, query):
    return ga_service.search(customer_id=customer_id, query=query, page_size=100)


def create_remove_ad_group_audience_operation(client, account_id, resource_name):
    ad_group_criterion_operation = client.get_type(
        "AdGroupCriterionOperation", version="v2"
    )
    ad_group_criterion_operation.remove = resource_name

    return ad_group_criterion_operation


if __name__ == "__main__":
    for i in range(500):
        process = psutil.Process(os.getpid())
        print(f"{str(i)}, {process.memory_percent()}")
        main()
    print(f"Final, {process.memory_percent()}")
```

The script records it's memory usage as we do 500 iterations and we've seen it steadily climbing, until the python process is using 13% of my the machine's memory, although I believe it would keep going until it crashed:
```
0, 0.3954887390136719
1, 0.6936073303222656
2, 0.7245063781738281
3, 0.7512569427490234
4, 0.78125
...
497, 13.024187088012695
498, 13.04483413696289
499, 13.071012496948242
Final, 13.090181350708008
```
When I tried this same idea with keywords we **did not see the same problem** - the memory usage returned to a low level after about 30 iterations (about 2% memory usage). 

This particular script was on python 3.7.0, google-ads 4.1.1, macos 10.14.6. We've also seen the same problem running this script on google-ads <= 3, and running our initial script on ubuntu 18.04 and python 3.7.5.

Full files can be found here:
[googleadstesting.zip](https://github.com/googleads/google-ads-python/files/4203719/googleadstesting.zip)

items.title: Field mask using protobuf_helpers leaves out path
items.body:
Hi,

I'm trying to use this library to switch bidding strategies on campaigns. When I try switching to Manual CPC the `protobuf_helpers.field_mask` to seems to drop the "manual_cpc.enhanced_cpc_enabled" path, resulting in no change at all. 

I know we can add the path in anyway but it makes things a lot tidier if `protobuf_helpers.field_mask` handled this case as nicely as it handles everything else I've given it. 

Also, it might be useful to have an example or two where we see how to create/modify a field mask rather than just having it inferred, just in case there are other examples of this issue.

Thanks!

Sample code:
````
def switch_campaign_bidding_strategy(client, campaign_resource_name, new_bidding_strategy, default_cpa_bid=5.0):
    campaign_operation = client.get_type('CampaignOperation', version='v2')
    campaign = campaign_operation.update

    campaign.resource_name = campaign_resource_name

    if new_bidding_strategy == "MANUAL_CPC":
        campaign.manual_cpc.enhanced_cpc_enabled.value = False
    elif new_bidding_strategy == "ENHANCED_CPC":
        campaign.manual_cpc.enhanced_cpc_enabled.value = True
    elif new_bidding_strategy == "TARGET_CPA":
        campaign.target_cpa.target_cpa_micros.value = int(default_cpa_bid * 1e6)

    field_mask = protobuf_helpers.field_mask(None, campaign)
    
    # The next two lines were added to fix the issue. Without them the manual cpc path is left out of the mask.
    if new_bidding_strategy == "MANUAL_CPC" and "manual_cpc.enhanced_cpc_enabled" not in field_mask.paths:
        field_mask.paths.append("manual_cpc.enhanced_cpc_enabled")

    campaign_operation.update_mask.CopyFrom(field_mask)

    return campaign_operation
````

items.title: Transient errors not raising exceptions
items.body:
Hi

With the old AdWords API Python module, any kind of concurrent modification or rate errors etc were raised as an exception, even when partial failures was used. This made it very easy to catch the exception and then retry the mutate operation.

From what I can tell in the new module, an exception is not raised, and this error e.g. "Too many requests. Retry in 30 seconds." is just assigned to each operation in the partial failure response.

What do you suggest as a best practice to identify these transient retryable errors? Is it best to just check the response for each operation to see if these errors are present and then retry, or is it possible to make these errors raise an exception so we can rely on the exception bubbling up to the caller where it can be handled?

Thanks!

items.title: Incorrect example in proto getters page
items.body:
In https://developers.google.com/google-ads/api/docs/client-libs/python/proto-getters, this is shown as an alternative to `campaign = client.get_type('Campaign')`:
```py
from google.ads.google_ads.v1.proto.resources import campaign_pb2
campaign = campaign_pb2()
```
Runnning this code gives a type error with the message `'module' object is not callable`, which makes sense given that campaign_pb2 actually is a module and not a type. Should it perhaps say this instead?
```py
from google.ads.google_ads.v1.proto.resources.campaign_pb2 import Campaign
campaign = Campaign()
```

items.title: GoogleAdsService.search returns InternalServerError for large WHERE filters
items.body:
When querying the `GoogleAdsService`, if the values in a WHERE filter exceed 15,000 items, then you can consistently get an `InternalServerError`.

An example query:

```python
    query = f"""
        SELECT
            ad_group.id,
            ad_group_ad.ad.id,
            ad_group_ad.ad.expanded_text_ad.headline_part1,
            ad_group_ad.ad.expanded_text_ad.headline_part2,
            ad_group_ad.ad.expanded_text_ad.headline_part3,
            ad_group_ad.ad.expanded_text_ad.description,
            ad_group_ad.ad.expanded_text_ad.description2,
            ad_group_ad.ad.expanded_text_ad.path1,
            ad_group_ad.ad.expanded_text_ad.path2,
            ad_group_ad.ad.final_urls,
            ad_group_ad.ad.type,
            ad_group_ad.status
        FROM ad_group_ad
        WHERE ad_group.id IN {google_adgroup_ids_tuple}
    """
```

where `google_adgroup_ids_tuple` is a tuple of ids. 

At the very least, I wouldn't expect to get an InternalServerError here. I would expect a more informative error. I only found this issue through trail and error (after having a hunch that it might be because the query is too big).

items.title: Can't update single target_restrictions for adgroup without supplying all other target_restrictions you don't want to update
items.body:
Hey @wihl 

You'de asked we make a github ticket to track this issue. It's kind of a follow on from issue #62 .
Strictly speaking it's not a case of entirely missing functionality like #62 was but rather reduced functionality which makes it hard to perform certain operations.

There appears to be some subtle difference in how the AdWords API and Google Ads API handle the values in the list of target_restrictions.
In the v201809 AdWords API one was able to update the targetAll value for a single CriterionTypeGroups (v201809 AdWords API) / target_restriction (Google Ads API) without needing to supply values for all the demographics that exist under the target_setting.
On the new Google Ads API one appears to be required to supply all target_restrictions otherwise the server throws an error (which appears to be unrelated to what I'm guessing is the actual underlying cause)

The error returned (below in it's entirety) is "TARGETING_SETTING_CANNOT_CHANGE_TARGET_ALL_TO_FALSE_FOR_DEMOGRAPHIC_CRITERION_TYPE_GROUP" with the error message "TargetingSetting cannot change any of the Demographic CriterionTypeGroups (AGE_RANGE, GENDER, PARENT, INCOME_RANGE) from true to false."
As you can see from our GRPC payload we are not attempting to modify the target_restrictions for the targeting_dimentions related to AGE_RANGE, GENDER, PARENTAL_STATUS or INCOME_RANGE. 
However the server appears to be assuming that due to their absence they are supposed to be updated to some undefined value. 
This undefined value appears to be causing the error handling to trip that is related to the attribute "targetAll" "false" (V201809 AdWords API) or "bid_only" "true" (Google Ads API).
Given this adgroup when downloaded with Google Ads API from Google indicates that all of the target_dimensions above already have a value of "targetAll" "false" (V201809 AdWords API) or "bid_only" "true" (Google Ads API), I'm relatively certain that the error is entirely unrelated.

So my question is two fold:
1) Can the API be updated so it behaved like the AdWords API and only attempt to apply the target_restrictions which are actually sent? (rather than attempting to set some default/invalid value for target_restrictions which are not sent and generating an error).
2) If not does this imply going forward that any attributes which are "Repeated" (https://developers.google.com/google-ads/api/docs/fields/ad_group#ad_grouptargeting_settingtarget_restrictions) are going to require us to send all already set values as part of any update operations? (with the AdWords API it was often the case that we only needed to send values that were actually being changed)

I believe two cases where the current situation might be limiting are:
1) If a user makes a change to a targetRestriction on Google and then makes a change to a different targetRestriction in locally we will by default need to replace the change made in Google, unless we request the targetRestrictions set on Google before making any mutate request.
2) If Google requires a specific targetRestriction we don't have locally, we will likely get an error back (similar to the one mentioned below). This could in some cases be remedied by requesting any new targetRestrictions that we might be missing from Google. But it's hard to know if the values would always be returned.

Peter

4 request response samples below indicating behavior detailed above:
Failing UPDATE with only one changed targetRestrictions set (Google Ads API)
Successful UPDATE with all targetRestrictions set (Google Ads API)
Successful GET showing all targetRestrictions set (Google Ads API)
Successful UPDATE with only one changed setting.details set (v201809 AdWords API)

```
Failing UPDATE with only one changed targetRestrictions set (Google Ads API):
=============================================================================
Request
-------
Method: /google.ads.googleads.v1.services.AdGroupService/MutateAdGroups
Host: googleads.googleapis.com:443
Headers: {
  "developer-token": "REDACTED",
  "login-customer-id": "6715128853",
  "x-goog-api-client": "gl-python/2.7.12 grpc/1.14.2 gax/1.4.1 gapic/1.1.1"
}
Request: {
  "operations": [
    {
      "update": {
        "resourceName": "customers/6715128853/adGroups/69225813358",
        "targetingSetting": {
          "targetRestrictions": [
            {
              "bidOnly": false,
              "targetingDimension": "AUDIENCE"
            }
          ]
        }
      },
```

items.title: Please run this script with UTF-8 encoding to avoid errors.
items.body: Hello, I've recently started to discover Adwords APIs. After finally reaching the last step "Make your first API call", I get the following error : "Your default encoding, cp1252, is not UTF-8. Please run this script with UTF-8 encoding to avoid errors." Yet, when I check the default encoding on my system, it says it's UTF-8. I've read many issues related to this error. I tried to find other ways to run the scripts to avoid this error. What would you suggest me to do ? Thank you for your help, Sarine

items.title: Make first-time authentication easier
items.body: I think it would be helpful to add a link to the [Configuration file setup](https://github.com/googleads/google-ads-python#configuration-file-setup) section of the README of the [OAuth Installed Application Flow](https://github.com/googleads/google-ads-python/wiki/OAuth-Installed-Application-Flow) rather than links to the Auth guide/samples. With the wiki, it's much easier and quicker to get started than following the existing links.

items.title: Unexpected empty result when selecting ad_group.id from feed_item
items.body:
I am noticing a strange behavior with the table `feed_item`. 
I created some ads that are using an ad customizer in my test account and if I try to execute the following query:

```python
In [78]:         query = f""" 
    ...:             SELECT 
    ...:                  feed_item.id, 
    ...:                  feed_item.attribute_values 
    ...:             FROM feed_item  
    ...:         """ 
    ...:
    ...:         ga_service = client.get_service('GoogleAdsService')
    ...:         results = ga_service.search(customer_id, query=query, page_size=100) 
    ...:  
    ...:         for row in results: 
    ...:             print(row)
```

I obtain some values as output:
```
feed_item {
  resource_name: "customers/2740564982/feedItems/94104567~69224194280"
  id {
    value: 69224194280
  }
  attribute_values {
    feed_attribute_id {
      value: 1
    }
    string_value {
      value: "Moodstreet"
    }
  }
}


feed_item {
  resource_name: "customers/2740564982/feedItems/94104567~69224194295"
  id {
    value: 69224194295
  }
  attribute_values {
    feed_attribute_id {
      value: 1
    }
    string_value {
      value: "Qtie"
    }
  }
}
.....other feed_item....
```

Using the `Interactive Google Ads Query Builder` I built this query (I added `ad_group.id)`:

```python
In [78]:         query = f""" 
    ...:             SELECT 
    ...:                  feed_item.id, 
    ...:                  feed_item.attribute_values, 
    ...:                  ad_group.id 
    ...:             FROM feed_item  
    ...:         """ 
    ...:  
    ...:         results = ga_service.search(customer_id, query=query, page_size=100) 
    ...:  
    ...:         for row in results: 
    ...:             print(row) 
    ...:                                                                                                                                                                                                    

In [79]:               
```

But the result, as you can see, is empty.
I found this strange, I would expect the same result as above with the field `ad_group.id`. Do you have an idea why this is happening?

I am using the `google-ads` version `2.0.0`.

Thanks for the help.

items.title: Google My Business Location Extensions
items.body:
Hello,

I'm trying to figure out how to create a GMB feed for location extensions in the new ads api.
There are no docs (that i can find) so i'm going off of the adwords api https://developers.google.com/adwords/api/docs/guides/feed-services-locations.

This adwords api says for the feed.origin to be `ADWORDS`. But that option is not listed in the new feed.origin enum at https://developers.google.com/google-ads/api/docs/fields/feed#feedorigin.

Is there any help i could find for creating GMB location extensions in the new google ads api anywhere. 
Thanks for any help.

items.title: Getting headers
items.body: Currently I'm able to extract the headers (for CSV output) from the query response using a set of procedure that goes as follows: convert message to dictionary MessageToDict(), flatten dictionary, get all keys in dictionary. It seems to work most of the time. However I noticed there are scenarios where I'm unable to get the full header, this happens when the returned rows have NULL values for some SELECT fields. It seems like the underlying protobuf message does not include a field if the value is NULL. I tried adding some custom logic to check the header on each row but that felt greasy. Is there a better way to get all the headers? Thanks in advance.

items.title: Not receiving correct value for ad_group_ad.ad.type
items.body:
For the supplied example ad_group_ad.ad.type returns ```0```, which corresponds to ```UNSPECIFIED``` using the [```AdTypeEnum```](https://github.com/googleads/google-ads-python/blob/master/google/ads/google_ads/v1/services/enums.py#L974).

While using the Google AdWords API the ```type``` field returns the correct type for the add, in case of the example provided this is ```EXPANDED_TEXT_AD```.

<details>
<summary>Google Adwords API example data</summary>

```
{
  'adGroupId': 67786249598,
  'ad': {
    'id': 343989679602,
    'url': None,
    'displayUrl': None,
    'finalUrls': [
      'https://channable.com'
    ],
    'finalMobileUrls': [
      
    ],
    'finalAppUrls': [
      
    ],
    'trackingUrlTemplate': None,
    'finalUrlSuffix': None,
    'urlCustomParameters': None,
    'urlData': [
      
    ],
    'automated': None,
    'type': 'EXPANDED_TEXT_AD',
    'devicePreference': None,
    'systemManagedEntitySource': None,
    'Ad.Type': 'ExpandedTextAd',
    'headlinePart1': 'h11',
    'headlinePart2': 'h22',
    'headlinePart3': None,
    'description': 'd1',
    'description2': None,
    'path1': None,
    'path2': None
  },
  'status': 'ENABLED',
  'policySummary': None,
  'labels': [
    
  ],
  'baseCampaignId': None,
  'baseAdGroupId': None,
  'forwardCompatibilityMap': [
    
  ],
  'adStrengthInfo': None
}
```

</details>


<details>
<summary>Google Ads API example data</summary>

```
{
  'adGroupId': 67786249598,
  'ad': {
    'id': 343989679602,
    'finalUrls': 'https://channable.com',
    'headlinePart1': 'h11',
    'headlinePart2': 'h22',
    'headlinePart3': '',
    'description': 'd1',
    'description2': '',
    'path1': '',
    'path2': '',
    'status': 'ENABLED',
    'type': 'UNSPECIFIED'
  }
}
```

</details>

The Google AdWords example is queried using:

```python
query = f"""
            SELECT Id, Status, AdGroupId, HeadlinePart1, HeadlinePart2, ExpandedTextAdHeadlinePart3,
                   Description, ExpandedTextAdDescription2, Path1, Path2, CreativeFinalUrls, Type
             WHERE AdGroupId IN {adgroup_ids}
             LIMIT {offset}, {limit}
        """
```
And the Google Ads example is queried using:
```python
query = f"""
            SELECT
                ad_group_ad.ad.id,
                ad_group_ad.status,
                ad_group.id,
                ad_group_ad.ad.expanded_text_ad.headline_part1,
                ad_group_ad.ad.expanded_text_ad.headline_part2,
                ad_group_ad.ad.expanded_text_ad.headline_part3,
                ad_group_ad.ad.expanded_text_ad.description,
                ad_group_ad.ad.expanded_text_ad.description2,
                ad_group_ad.ad.expanded_text_ad.path1,
                ad_group_ad.ad.expanded_text_ad.path2,
                ad_group_ad.ad.final_urls
                ad_group_ad.ad.type
            FROM ad_group_ad
            WHERE ad_group.id IN ({formatted_adgroup_ids})
              AND ad_group_ad.status in ({status.value})
        """
```

Which throws an exception: 

    Request made: ClientCustomerId: XXX-XXX-XXXX, Host: googleads.googleapis.com:443, Method: /google.ads.googleads.v1.services.GoogleAdsService/Search, RequestId: None, IsFault: True, FaultMessage: DNS resolution failed

and

	status = StatusCode.UNAVAILABLE
	details = "DNS resolution failed"
	debug_error_string = "{"created":"@1555542001.640383000","description":"Failed to create subchannel","file":"src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/client_channel.cc","file_line":2715,"referenced_errors":[{"created":"@1555541990.752433000","description":"Resolver transient failure","file":"src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolving_lb_policy.cc","file_line":335,"referenced_errors":[{"created":"@1555541990.752432000","description":"DNS resolution failed","file":"src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/dns_resolver_ares.cc","file_line":326,"grpc_status":14,"referenced_errors":[{"created":"@1555541990.752381000","description":"C-ares status is not ARES_SUCCESS: DNS query cancelled","file":"src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper.cc","file_line":240,"referenced_errors":[{"created":"@1555541990.752374000","description":"C-ares status is not ARES_SUCCESS: DNS query cancelled","file":"src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper.cc","file_line":240}]}]}]}]}"

items.title: How do you compare `ErrorCode`s?
items.body:
If I have the following:

```python
        results = ga_service.search(self.client_customer_id, query=query, page_size=page_size)

        try:
            yield from results

        except GoogleAdsException as ex:
            <'error handling here'>
```

There is a lot of information in `ex`. The examples in this repo print the exception `request_id` and the name of the status (`ex.error.code().name`)

Instead of accessing the status, which can be general, I want to access the actual failures, 
`ex.failure.errors`. 

```python
for error in ex.failure.errors:
    if error.code == <'not sure what to do here'>:
        <'process individual failure'>
```

---
A use-case I have is that I want to trigger a certain code path if we receive a `CLIENT_CUSTOMER_ID_INVALID` and a different one if we get a `CUSTOMER_NOT_ACTIVE`. Using the `StatusCode`, both of these errors have a status of `UNAUTHENTICATED`. 

My thoughts are that you need to create your own `ErrorCode`, but I am not having success with that using
```python
error_code = client.get_type('ErrorCode', version='v1')
```

Any ideas?

items.body:
Hi,

Here's the code:
```

conversion_upload_service.upload_click_conversions(<customer_id>, <conversions>, <partial_failure>)
```

```
    six.raise_from(exceptions.from_grpc_error(exc), exc)

    raise value
google.api_core.exceptions.InternalServerError: 500 Internal error encountered.
```

errors from `google.api_core.exceptions.GoogleAPICallError` shows me:

```python
asset = asset_operation.create
```

Could someone help me out with this issue? Happy to document and contribute more info if needed. Thanks for your time!

items.title: provide dynamically loading client settings by object instead of using load_by_string

labels.name: P2
labels.description: Work that should be prioritized. Bugs classified here have known reasonable workarounds.

items.body:
Following the example, we need to make a yaml file to set client settings and use `GoogleAdsClient.load_from_storage` to create a new client instance, but it does not make sense in production service that provides multiple customers to fetch their ads.

My current solution is like this,
```python
   configuration_string = '\n'.join([
        'developer_token: %s' % developer_token,
        'client_id: %s' % client_id,
        'client_secret: %s' % client_secret,
        'refresh_token: %s' % refresh_token,
        'login_customer_id: %s' % login_customer_id
    ])
    client = google.ads.google_ads.client.GoogleAdsClient.load_from_string(configuration_string)
```
I use `GoogleAdsClient.load_from_string` to make a string as yaml format, but I think it had better provide a function to load settings by dictionary(object), and it will be more easy to use.
